GT_Sentence: an analysis released in august of respondents to the 2022 u.s. transgender survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the u.s. population. the study included more than 92,000 respondents, including more than 84,000 adults who were 18 and older.

“trans votes count,” said ankit rastogi, director of research for the national center for transgender equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as advocates for trans equality education fund. “i think the big takeaway is that our community is really trying to come out and make a difference through the democratic process.”
